awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Adaptive Power Management for Multiprocessor System-on-Chip
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Adaptive Power Management for Multiprocessor System-on-Chip

Multiprocessor System-on-Chip (MPSoC) is becoming a major VLSI system design platform due to its advantages in low design cost and high performance. However, power consumption in MPSoC is a crucial factor that is limiting the growth of system performance and functionality. The complexity of the MPSoC hardware and software imposes new challenges and requirements for research in system-level power management.
An effective power manager must be aware of the status of the hardware, the application and the working environment and be able to adapt to the changes. It should be able to work robustly even if the perfect system information is not available. As the number of components that can be power controlled increases, it is increasingly difficult to perform power management in a centralized manner. A hierarchical and distributed power management method is more suitable for MPSoC platforms. Finally, resource management, power management, and thermal management are inter-correlated tasks and it is desirable for them to be optimized simultaneously.
This research project addresses the above mentioned challenges by investigating the theoretical foundation and the applied framework of adaptive power management for the next generation MPSoC. This project consists of four research components: (1) investigate online modeling techniques for runtime workload prediction and hardware performance/power characterization; (2) research new optimization techniques for adaptive resource and power management in a partially observable system; (3) model the distributed power management problem as a multi-agent cooperative game and develop control policy using game theory; (4) develop a unified and standard platform for modeling, optimization and evaluation of power-managed MPSoC.
The educational components of this project will introduce the students to the implementation and optimization techniques of system-level power management and provide students unique hands-on experience with MPSoC design and optimization.

por.por_cntn:
In order to sustain the growth of information technology and to enable new applications on computing devices, their energy dissipation and heat generation must be carefully managed. Four major challenges in today’s computing systems hinder the effective power and thermal management. First of all, modern computing device is a dynamic system. Not only does its workload constantly changing, the user expectation of its speed and response time also varies from application to application. It is almost not possible to configure a computing device to the right power mode or speed level, without any knowledge about its future workload and user performance requirements. Secondly, the vast variety in the existing computing devices imposes challenges in the design of effective power/thermal management policy. The policy works for general purpose PC may not work well for mobile device. Thirdly, the widely use of multicore processors increases the complexity of power/thermal management problem. Without careful design, the complexity will increase exponentially as the number of cores/processors increases. Finally, it has been generally accepted that the ultimate solution to achieve energy autonomy is through environmental energy harvesting.  However, the uncertainty of the harvested energy and the efficiency of the energy harvesting, converting and storage units add another layer of complexity to the power management problem. There is an urgent need to investigate power/thermal management policy that responds to the changing workload and user performance requirement, adapts to different hardware, maintains a constant complexity regardless of the scale of the hardware system, and makes decisions with the awareness of the available energy and efficiency of the power systems.

In this project we investigate adaptive power and thermal management techniques with above mentioned properties. By adopting research advances in machine learning and stochastic control, the power and thermal management algorithms developed in this project do not need detailed prior information on the workload or hardware architecture but learn from the environment and runtime characterization. Our research shows that different modeling techniques should be used to predict the workload requirement or to estimate the power, temperature and performance of a power managed system.  Compared to existing approaches, our hidden Markov based workload model gives higher likelihood of observed workload sequence; our neural network based temperature and performance model trained with principal component analysis has higher correlation with measure data. Based on the models, power/thermal management policies were designed to effectively manage the power modes or voltage/frequency levels of computing hardware and dynamically configure the QoS settings of application software according to the resource availability, workload status, and user performance requirements. Compared to existing approaches, our adaptive power/thermal management controllers are always capable of providing wider range of energy performance tradeoff with higher optimality. In order to reduce the complexity, model free reinforcement learning is applied to power/thermal management, where we skip the model construction and directly learn the management policy. The framework of distributed management was proposed and evaluated, which has a constant complexity by making decision only based on local information. Six journal publications and more than 10 conference publications have been generated from this research.
